journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Multiple-input describing function technique applied to design a single channel ON-OFF controller for a spinning flight vehicle

article-meta.aff: Guidance and Control Research Core, Center of Excellence in Aerospace Systems, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Guidance and Control Research Core, Center of Excellence in Aerospace Systems, Sharif University of Technology, P.O. Box: 11365-11155, Tehran, Iran. email: nobahari@sharif.edu

abstract.p: In this study, the guidance and control problem of a single-channel spinning missile is investigated. The missile utilizes a single ON-OFF actuator to drive a pair of control surfaces (e.g. elevators) and consequently to perform all required lateral maneouvers. An approximated linear response of the so-called non-rotating frame to ON-OFF input, applied to the rotating frame, is derived using the multiple-input describing function technique. It is shown that there is a relationship between the response of the non-rotating frame and that of the equivalent non-rotating body. It is also shown that the two-channel flight controller, designed for the equivalent non-rotating body, can be reduced to a single-channel controller, the output of which is applied to the rotating body. A necessary condition is introduced for this purpose. A proportional navigation guidance law for such a spinning missile is also introduced that generates an angular rate command instead of the acceleration command. Finally, the performance of the proposed controller in the presence of noise and uncertainties is validated through flight simulations.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: A large variety of shoulder-launched missiles, intelligent anti-armour projectiles, guided rockets, re-entry vehicles, and satellites spin during flight. For a spinning re-entry vehicle the main goal is to stabilize the vehicle using gyroscopic effects. For a shoulder-launched missile the spin allows the missile to be controlled using only a single actuator and a pair of control surfaces. A single channel flight control system has a smaller size, lower cost, and is lighter compared with two/three channel controllers. A low weight results in higher portability for shoulder-launched missiles. The presence of spin also stabilizes a shoulder-launched missile during the early low-speed stage of flight during which the aerodynamic forces and moments are not strong enough to stabilize the missile. It also reduces the undesired dynamic effects of thrust asymmetries, fin misalignments, and some measurement errors.

This paper discusses the design of a single channel autopilot for a spinning shoulder-launched missile. The dynamics and control of a spinning missile have been extensively discussed in the literature. The effects of spin on the aerodynamic coefficients were reported in [1–4]. The single plane simulation of a rolling missile was provided in [5]. A criterion for stability analysis of an ablating symmetric spinning re-entry vehicle was derived in [6]. A method for determining the admissible tolerances of a spinning missile was presented in [7]. The effect of spin rate on miss distance was studied in [8]. A practical method to control the angle-of-attack of a spinning re-entry vehicle was described in [9]. In [10] the homing of a missile, guided by proportional navigation (PN), was solved in closed form in the presence of a periodic roll rate. A method for limiting cross-range dispersion of spinning missiles was introduced in [11] and the effect of lift non-averaging on the dispersion of a spinning missile was discussed in [12]. The dynamic analysis of a nose cone, jettisoned from a spinning rocket, was investigated in [13]. An analytical approach to quantify the dynamic effects of a lateral square impulse, disturbing a projectile during free flight, was presented in [14]. In that approach a complete aerodynamic model, including Magnus effects, was derived and a closed-form solution for the swerving motion of the spinning projectile was obtained. A generalized control model for spin-stabilized projectiles was formulated in [15]; it was subsequently used to investigate the effect of parameters such as control force magnitude, control axial location, and control lift-to-drag ratio on flight characteristics.

In non-rolling missiles the pitch and yaw dynamics are independent of one another and thus it is possible to model these dynamics as two independent single-input single-output (SISO) transfer functions. However, for spinning missiles, even for symmetric configurations, the roll motion causes the pitch and yaw channels to be coupled and the missile has to be modelled as a multi-input multi-output (MIMO) system.

An approach to avoid encountering a MIMO control problem has been proposed by [16–18]. The proposed approach requires the use of a non-rotating frame which allows the missile to be modelled as a set of SISO transfer functions. In this approach it is assumed that the instantaneous roll angle between the rotating and non-rotating frames is available during the flight. However, it will be shown in this paper that for a class of spinning missiles, there is no need to use this angle to calculate the commands. Moreover, utilizing this decoupling technique to synthesize single channel controllers does not tackle the disturbances that occur due to the projection of the two perpendicular control signal into a single pair of control surfaces.

The actuators of spinning missiles, from a performance point of view, are classified into two main categories: ON-OFF types with discrete outputs and proportional types with continuous outputs. An ON-OFF actuator is usually simpler than a proportional actuator but it increases the non-linearity of the flight control system. ON-OFF actuators have been used for time-optimal attitude control of spacecraft [19–23] and spinning missiles [24, 25]. Lateral pulse jets have also been proposed for the lateral control of spinning rockets and missiles [26, 27]. The use of a proportional actuator to control a single channel shoulder-launched missile was studied in [28, 29]. Malmgren [28] derived the dynamic model of the non-rotating frame based on the average response of the rotating frame to the actuator deflection. Using this model, the linear fractional transformation method was then utilized to design the controller. Lestage [29] derived a dynamic model to describe the response of the non-rotating frame to the continuous input, applied to the rotating frame. This model is a constant fraction of the transfer function, obtained for a non-rotating body, plus an output disturbance. It should be noted that this disturbance is due to the projection of the two perpendicular control signals into a single pair of control surfaces and is therefore not considered in the papers that used the transfer functions of the non-rotating frame [16–18]. Lestage used the proposed model to synthesize controllers for the pitch and yaw control loops of the non-rotating frame. Assuming that the roll angle is known, the outputs of the two controllers were then transformed from the non-rotating frame to the rotating frame to allow them to be applied to the single pair of control surfaces.

The design and implementation details of a single channel ON-OFF controller that can be used for a homing shoulder-launched missile is presented in this paper. As an extension to the work presented in [29], it is shown that the response of the non-rotating frame to ON-OFF actuation in the rotating frame can be derived using the multiple-input describing function technique [30]. In this method a linearization signal is added to the control loop to linearize the non-linear element. It will be shown that, in the presence of an ON-OFF actuator instead of a continuous one, a new disturbance term is added to the system transfer function; it is originated from the addition of the linearization signal. Moreover, the gain of this transfer function is a function of the linearization signal amplitude, as well as the maximum actuator deflection. The same approach as in [29] is utilized to design the controller. However, it will be shown that imposing an extra constraint on the designed controller, the two control channels in the non-rotating frame (as illustrated in [29]) can be replaced with a single channel in the rotating frame. Therefore, the control task can be accomplished using only one rate gyro. Moreover, it will be shown that the content of the information signal, provided by the seeker, obviates the need to measure the roll angle.

The roll motion also imposes some difficulties in using the accelerometer to measure the lateral accelerations. It will be shown that in a shoulder-launched missile there is no need to use the accelerometer to execute the PN guidance law and it can be executed using the existing rate gyro.

The organization of this paper is as follows: section 2 deals with the mathematical representation of the problem. The response of the non-rotating frame to ON-OFF actuation in the rotating frame is derived in section 3. Section 4 describes the implementation issues regarding a single-channel controller. Section 5 presents the simulation results and concluding remarks are provided in section 6.

sec.title: 2 PROBLEM FORMULATION
sec.p: In this section, the mathematical model of the problem is formulated. First, the proper form of the PN guidance law for a homing shoulder-launched missile is introduced. Second, the linearized four-degree-of-freedom equations of motion for an axisymmetric airframe are derived. Then, the transfer functions of the rotating and non-rotating frames are derived. Finally, the single control surface is modelled based on the relation between the rotating and non-rotating frames.

sec.title: 2.1 Guidance law
sec.p: The guidance law of a homing shoulder-launched missile is introduced in this section. Here, the common PN with lateral acceleration commands is reformulated to be executed using a rate gyro instead of an accelerometer. According to PN guidance, the flight-path frame (V) should be rotated proportional to the angular velocity of the line-of-sight frame (L) (1) where ωVI and ωLI are the angular velocity vector of the flight-path frame and the line-of-sight frame with respect to the inertial frame (I), respectively, written in matrix form and N is the navigation coefficient. The representation of ωLI in the line-of-sight frame can be written as follows (2)

The seeker of a spinning shoulder-launched missile measures a combination of qL and rL. If the total angle of attack is assumed to be small, one can use the following approximation as the guidance law for a shoulder-launched missile (3) where ωSI is the angular velocity of the non-rotating frame (S) with respect to the inertial frame. The non-rotating frame, defined in this paper, has the same pitch and yaw rates, as the body frame, and no roll rate with respect to the inertial frame. The expression of ωSI in the non-rotating frame can be written as follows (4) where q0c and r0c are the pitch and yaw angular rate commands in the non-rotating frame, respectively. Therefore, if sensor(s) and actuator(s) are available to measure and modify q0 and r0 or a combination of them, the measured signal(s) can be controlled to follow the commanded values (q0c and r0c) or the combination of them. A detailed description of this problem is provided in section 4.

sec.title: 2.2 Linearized four-degree-of-freedom equations of motion
sec.p: The general equations of motion of a rigid body in space are non-linear. Using simplifying assumptions and linearization techniques, these equations can be simplified into a set of linear equations from which the transfer functions can be derived. These linearized equations can be written as follows [31] (5) (6)

Equation (5) is the linearized form of the linear momentum equation for a rigid body, expressed in the perturbed body coordinate system (Bp) which differs from the reference body coordinate system (Br) by the imposed perturbations to the steady state flight condition (SSFC). In this equation, m is the flight vehicle mass, ε is the perturbation operator, and ɛvB I is the perturbation of inertial velocity relative to SSFC. Also, ΩBrI is the skew symmetric matrix form of the inertial angular velocity of the reference body coordinate system and ɛΩBI is the perturbation of the inertial angular velocity of the body coordinate system relative to SSFC in the skew symmetric matrix form. Finally, ɛfa, ɛft, and ɛfg are the perturbation of the aerodynamic, thrust, and gravitational forces relative to SSFC, respectively.

Equation (6) is the linearized form of the angular momentum equation for a rigid body, expressed in Bp. Here, IBp Bp and IBr Br are the moments of inertia in Bp and Br, respectively and ɛωBI is the perturbation of the inertial angular velocity of the body coordinate system relative to SSFC. Also, ωBrI is the inertial angular velocity of the reference body coordinate system in SSFC and finally, ɛma and ɛmt are the perturbation of the aerodynamic and thrust moments relative to SSFC, respectively.
The mathematical definition of the variables, used in equations (5) and (6), are as follows (7) (8)
In equation (8), the missile has been assumed to be axisymmetric.

By ignoring the effects of gravity and thrust forces and moments on the transient response of the missile, only the aerodynamic forces and moments will remain. Considering only linear aerodynamic terms, [ɛfa]Bp would be [31] (9)

Here, ρr, q¯r, ar, and Vr are the air density, dynamic pressure, speed of sound, and vehicle speed in SSFC, respectively. Elevator and rudder deflections are shown with δe and δr, respectively and S denotes aerodynamic reference area. Finally, CAr, CAM, CAα, CAδe, CYβ, CYδr, CNr, CNM, CNα, and CNδe are the aerodynamic coefficients.

Similarly, [ɛma]Bp would be [31] (10) where b and c are lateral and longitudinal reference lengths, respectively, and Clβ, Clp, Clr, Clβ·, Clδa, Clδr, Cmr, CmM, Cmα, Cmq, Cmα·, Cmδe, Cnβ, Cnp, Cnr, Cnβ·, and Cnδr are the flight vehicle aerodynamic coefficients.
For a spinning flight vehicle, [vBr I]Br and [ωBrI]Br can be assumed as follows (11)

Substituting equations (7) to (11) into equations (5) and (6) and assuming ur and pr to be constant, the linearized four-degree-of-freedom equations of motion of an axisymmetric spinning missile would be (12) where (13)
In the derivation of equation (12), the following assumptions were made:

It should be noted that since the aerodynamic model does not include Magnus forces and moments, equation (12) is valid only for a slowly rolling missile and it is not valid for a rapidly spinning body such as a spin-stabilized projectile.

sec.title: 2.3 Transfer functions of the rotating and non-rotating frame
sec.p: Applying the Laplace transform to both sides of equation (12) and assuming zero initial values for the state variables leads to (14)
Thus, the linear model of the rotating frame is (15) where (16)
The expansion of G(s) is (17)
Here, pitch and yaw channels are coupled due to the vehicle spin. However, if one sets pr = 0, then G(s) will be simplified as follows: (18)
Comparing equations (16) and (18), one can observe that it is easier to control the non-rotating frame than the rotating frame, because:

list-item.p: Gpr=0(s) is a set of SISO transfer functions whereas G(s) is a MIMO system;
Gpr=0(s) represents a second-order system whereas G(s) represents a fourth- order system;
from the design point of view, the effects of parameters in Gpr=0(s) is more sensible than in G(s)

sec.p: In section 3, it will be shown that for a rotating body, the response of the non-rotating frame to the control signal, applied to the rotating frame is a function of Gpr=0(s).

sec.title: 2.4 Modelling of the single control surface
sec.p:
Due to the restriction on mass and dimensions, the shoulder-launched missiles are usually preferred to have a single control loop and thus a single actuator and a single pair of control surfaces. Therefore, the missile is assumed to have no rudder. Figure 1 presents the relation between the rotating and the non-rotating frames. The rotating frame has been rolled by an angle ξ = pt with respect to the non-rotating frame; Thus, if δe0(t) and δr0(t) are the required deflections in the non-rotating frame, the required elevator deflection in the rotating frame, can be computed as follows Fig. 1
Relation between rotating and non-rotating frames (19)

sec.title: 3 DYNAMIC RESPONSE OF THE NON-ROTATING FRAME TO SINGLE ON-OFF ACTUATION IN ROTATING BODY
sec.p:
The ON-OFF actuator can be represented as an ideal relay. Using the multiple input describing functions technique it is possible to approximate the non-linear behaviour of an ideal relay with a linear mathematical model. In this method, the relay is linearized by adding a secondary signal (called the linearization signal) to its input. Consider an ideal relay with characteristics defined in Fig. 2.In this figure, Asin(ωt) is the linearization signal. According to [30], the relay output can be approximated by Fig. 2
Linearization of an ideal relay (20) where NA(A,B) and NB(A,B) are defined as follows (21)
Replacing ω with p/pγ γ and assuming B/A to be small enough, the high-order terms of NA(A,B) and NB(A,B) can be neglected. Therefore, equation (20) is simplified as follows (22)

It can be shown that for small values of the information signal, B, there is a linear relation between the average of y(t) in a complete revolution and B. It can also be shown that this average value is saturated for large values of B.
According to equation (19), the actuator input in Fig. 2 can be written as (23)
Utilizing equation (22), the actuator output (the elevator deflection in body frame), can be approximated as follows (24)

According to equation (24), it can again be shown that there is a linear relation between the average elevator deflection in a complete revolution, δ¯eo(t), and the total required deflections in the non-rotating frame (δ0(t)=[δe0(t)]2+[δr0(t)]2), for small values of δ0(t). Again, this average value is saturated for large values of δ0(t).

As stated in section 2.3, it is desirable to derive the response of the non-rotating frame to the single ON-OFF actuator deflection in the rotating body. Suppose that the non-rotating frame has two imaginary pairs of control surfaces. Also, suppose that the controllers of the non-rotating frame compensate the guidance errors and generate the required deflections in the non-rotating frame from which the required elevator deflection in the rotating body can be calculated.
Taking a Laplace transform of equation (24) and utilizing the concept of complex variables, equations (15) can be rewritten as follows (25)
Now consider the following definition as proposed in [29] (26)
Referring to [29], that studied a spinning missile with proportional actuators, the relation between the response of the rotating and non-rotating frames can be derived as follows (27)
Also, [29] has shown that (28)
Combining equations (25), (27), and (28) leads to (29)

In equation (29), the matrices
are not diagonal and cause the system to be coupled. However, it can be shown that if δe0(t) and δr0(t) are assumed to be approximately constant within a half period of a complete revolution, i.e. δe0(t)=δe0 and δr0(t)=δr0, then the average effect of the corresponding terms in equation (29) will be nullified
(30)

In equation (30), gpr=0(t)=L-1{Gpr=0(s)} and g¯pr=0 is the average of gpr=0(t) in a half period of a complete revolution. Now, equation (29) can be rewritten as follows (31) where A is the amplitude of the linearization signal, δemax is the maximum elevator deflection, Gpr=0(s) is the transfer function of the non-rotating body, and 0¯2p(s) is the output disturbance which appears when two required deflections in the non-rotating frame are mapped into the single control surface of the rotating body. According to equation (30), this disturbance occurs at a frequency twice the spin rate. Finally, D0(s) is the output disturbance that appears when the linearization signal is added to the information signal. The later is defined as follows (32)
Equation (31) shows an uncoupled linear model for a spinning missile with a single ON-OFF control surface. It is now possible to design a SISO controller for such a system.

sec.title: 4 DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SINGLE CHANNEL CONTROLLER
sec.p: The controller design and implementation for a spinning missile is a conjugated problem. The most important implementation problem arises from the fact that the instantaneous angle between the rotating and non-rotating frames is not available. References [5, 8, 10, 16–18, 28, 29] have used the transformation matrix between the rotating and non-rotating frames. However, it will be shown that in a homing shoulder-launched missile there is no need to have this matrix.

Figure 3 shows how two controllers Cq0 and Cr0 could make the rolling missile follow the guidance commands q0c and r0c, if q0 and r0 were properly provided. The pitch and yaw controllers (Cq0 and Cr0) are designed utilizing equation (31) and the block diagram of Fig. 4. The output of these two controllers (δe0 and δr0) are mapped to δe. The lateral angular velocities (q and r) must then be measured using two rate gyros to provide q0 and r0 after transformation to the non-rotating frame. Fig. 3
Implementation of the controllers in the non-rotating frame Fig. 4
Block diagram constructed to design the controller in the non-rotating frame

It should be noted that two serial blocks of a block diagram can be swapped using the superposition principle. Moreover, since q0(s)/q0(s)δe0(s) δe0(s) and r0(s)/r0(s)δr0(s) δr0(s) in equation (31) are the same, the designed controllers (Cq0 and Cr0) will also be the same. Therefore, for such an axisymmetric missile the two-channel controller, shown in the block diagram of Fig. 3, can be rearranged in the form of the single-channel controller, presented in Fig. 5. Fig. 5
Reduction of the two-channel controller to a single-channel one

The controller (Cq0) in Figs 3, 4, 5 is the same in all cases. It should be noted that the missile spins at p rad/s and as a result eq is approximately a sinusoidal signal with the frequency of p rad/s. Therefore, in order for this superposition to be valid, Cq0 must be designed to properly pass this frequency. Figures 6 and 7 present simplified forms of the single control channel. Fig. 6
Vector sketch of the single-channel controller Fig. 7
Implementation of the single-channel controller

In Fig. 7 qc is the guidance command and it should be noted that the seeker of such a system measures the line-of-sight rate along the body pitch axis from which qc can be generated using the PN guidance law, as described in section 2. Therefore, all lateral maneouvers of a shoulder-launched missile can be controlled using only one rate gyro, in a single control loop. Moreover, there is no need for a transformation matrix between the rotating and non-rotating frames.

sec.title: 5 SIMULATION RESULTS
sec.p:
The parameters of a spinning missile at a given operating point are listed in Table 1. Also the maximum elevator deflection (δemax) and the actuator transfer function are taken π/π8 8 and 1/1(1+0.004s) (1+0.004s), respectively. Table 1
Parameters of the spinning missile
pr(rad/s) ur(m/s) Mw Mδe Mq Yv Yδr
Value 20 600 −0.667 60 −0.5 −5 0
Using Table 1 and equations (31) and (32), the pitch channel transfer function of the non-rotating frame and the disturbance caused by the linearization signal can be calculated as follows (33) (34)
The amplitude of the linearization signal (A) should be selected based on the maximum line-of-sight rate and the navigation coefficient. In this work, A=1/10 has been taken.

According to equation (34), limγ→0D0q(s)=0; but γ→0 corresponds to a linearization signal with infinite frequency, which is infeasible. Figure 8 shows the effect of γ on the peak magnitude and frequency of D0q. It can be observed that, decreasing γ decreases the maximum disturbance power, but this maximum occurs at a higher frequency and the corresponding disturbance is more difficult to eliminate. Thus, one should compromise between these two opposing effects. After some investigations based on the simulation results, γ=1/2 was chosen. Fig. 8
Frequency response of the disturbance signal for different values of γ

As mentioned previously, one of the most important points, not stated in the literature, is the constraint that the controller should properly pass the frequencies close to the missile’s spin rate (at this frequency, the magnitude and the phase of the closed-loop system and the phase of the open-loop system should be zero). Also, the controller should eliminate sensor noise as well as any disturbances. Using the linear control theory, a controller can be proposed as follows (35)

Figures 9 and 10 show the Bode diagram of the compensated open-loop and closed-loop systems, respectively. Fig. 9
Bode diagram of the compensated open-loop system Fig. 10
Bode diagram of the compensated closed-loop system

By assuming that the missile’s velocity and spin rate are constant, the performance of the proposed controller was evaluated using a four-degree-of-freedom flight simulation code, as in [29]. For this purpose, various manoeuvring and non-manoeuvring engagement scenarios were investigated, as defined in Table 2. In the manoeuvring scenarios the target starts a pull-up manoeuvre when the range-to-go becomes smaller than 1 km. The navigation coefficient was set equal to five in all scenarios. Table 2
Flight scenarios defined to evaluate the single-channel controller
Scenario [sTM]G|t=0(m) [vT G]G|t=0(m/s)
No. Type
1 Non-manoeuvring [5000 5000 −500] [0 −400 0]
2 Manoeuvring (3g) [4000 4000 −4000] [−200 −200 100]
3 Manoeuvring (6g) [5000 4000 −3000] [−500 0 0]
4 Manoeuvring (9g) [4000 4000 −1000] [−200 −200 0]

Table 3 presents the value of miss distance, obtained in different scenarios. The effects of seeker noise and plant uncertainties were also investigated using the flight simulation. The seeker noise was modelled as a white noise, the power of which was equal to one-tenth of the maximum line-of-sight rate. The plant uncertainties were considered in the form of a 10 per cent increase in d.c. gain, a 10 per cent decrease in damping ratio, and a 10 per cent decrease in natural frequency. The results show that the proposed controller has an acceptable performance in the presence of noise and uncertainties. Table 3
Performance of the single-channel guidance and control system evaluated using the flight simulation
Scenario Miss distance (m)
Without noise and uncertainty With noise With uncertainty in
Gain Natural frequency Damping Ratio
1 0.558 1.646 0.846 0.952 1.391
2 2.539 2.674 3.486 3.260 3.932
3 4.285 4.857 5.157 7.537 5.661
4 5.211 5.650 6.413 9.057 7.436

Figure 11 shows the engagement trajectories in different scenarios. Figure 12 shows the ON-OFF input, applied to the elevator. It can be seen that in the first parts of the flight, where the PN generates a large command, the linearization signal is resolved in the main information signal and does not contribute in generating the elevator deflection. However, since PN generates a decreasing command for N = 5 [32], in the last parts of the flight the effect of the linearization signal is clearly observed. Figure 13 shows the tracking of the guidance command. Here, the initially saturated PN command can be clearly observed, while in the last parts of the flight the magnitude of the guidance command is small enough to be successfully tracked. Fig. 11
Engagement trajectories in different scenarios Fig. 12
Elevator commands in different engagement scenarios Fig. 13
Tracking of the guidance commands in different engagement scenarios

The disturbance model, derived in this paper, can also be validated using the simulation results. Figure 8 shows that when γ=1/5, the maximum disturbance, the linearization signal adds to the pitch channel, occurs at the frequencies 80 and 120 rad/s. Taking the fast Fourier transform of the simulation results, the same result is obtained, as is shown in Fig. 14. In this figure the signal also has another peak at the frequency of 40 rad/s, which was previously been predicted by the term 0¯2p in equation (31). Fig. 14
Spectrum analysis of q0 based on the simulation results

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: From the roll control strategy point of view, missiles are classified into three classes: bank to turn (BTT), skid to turn (STT), and free to roll (FTR). The FTR class is the most challenging and there is a little published work in this class as compared to BTT and STT classes. In this paper the guidance and control problem of a FTR missile with a single ON-OFF control channel is studied. At first a feasible homing guidance law, suitable for a shoulder-launched missile was introduced. Then, the non-rotating frame was defined and the dynamic response of this frame to ON-OFF actuation in the rotating frame was modelled. Utilizing the multiple-input describing function technique, this non-linear model was then linearized in the form of a transfer function matrix. It was shown that this matrix is a function of the matrix derived for a non-rotating body, and that some new output disturbances occur in the model. These disturbances are the result of the addition of the linearization signal and also to the projection of the two perpendicular control signals into a single pair of control surfaces. It was also shown that one can use the transfer functions obtained for a non-rotating body to design the controller for a rotating body; however, some new design constraints are required. The controller should reject the new output disturbances. Moreover, it should properly pass frequencies close to the missile’s spin rate. In other words, the magnitude (in decibels) and the phase of the closed-loop system and the phase of the open-loop system should be zero at the spinning frequency. Implementation of the single channel ON-OFF controller in a shoulder-launched missile was also investigated in detail, which is the most challenging part of the problem. Finally, using a flight simulation code, the design and implementation of the single channel ON-OFF controller was validated in different manoeuvring and non- manoeuvring flight scenarios, taking the seeker noise and plant uncertainties into account.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
